metadata.title: Interesting AI/ML Related Articles I Came Across This Week (May 2nd) | by Richmond Alake | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Interesting AI/ML Related Articles I Came Across This Week (May 2nd)
metadata.description: The world of Artificial Intelligence never sleeps, and there are more interesting articles written by curious, intelligent and passionate writers on Medium. With a large number of people having more…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: rapper Jay Z takes action against deepfake content portraying attributes of himself on YouTube

all_paragraphs: The world of Artificial Intelligence never sleeps, and there are more interesting articles written by curious, intelligent and passionate writers on Medium.

With a large number of people having more time of their hands due to the lockdown, there’s been an increase in the amount of quality and informative content I seem to come across on Medium. Sadly, I can only write about a few.
Be prepared to encounter writers covering topics such as:
An interesting opinion piece from Luke Posey on the matter of the longevity of the Machine Learning Engineer role within the software industry.
Honestly speaking, when I read the title, I felt a little bit triggered. But after reading the content of the article, I can see where Luke is coming from.
Luke’s opinion on the disappearance of the Machine Learning role is based on the fact that the responsibilities associated with ML Engineering will merge into the broader Software Engineering role.

This article is a conversation starter, as the role of an ML Engineer is extensive and differs from company to company. Luke acknowledges the fact that there isn’t an industry-standard description for the role, so he provides three typical requirements for ML Engineering roles you’ll come across on job postings.

Luke also states an excellent point, and that is that the ML Engineer role could exist due to the ambiguity on what machine learning itself entails. Which leads on the statement that “by consequence, ML Engineers are in many cases half researcher, half engineer”.
This is a truth that I live every day, although one could argue that the balance is not necessarily 50/50.

Luke’s point is centred around the notion that as more people begin to understand ML, there might be less need for an ambiguous role such as an ML Engineer and the role itself will be engulfed in the more extensive Software Engineering role requirement.
I have barely scratched the surface of Luke Posey’s opinion piece.
Deepfake is retaking the spotlight, especially when world-famous rapper Jay Z takes action against deepfake content portraying attributes of himself on YouTube.

Dave Gershgorn article centres around the legal aspects of deepfakes and the legal actions that have been taken in the past against the use of similar creative/music style by a party that is not affiliated to the prosecutor.
Dave article provides an example of an AI-generated song, and it eerily indistinguishable from human-generated music (give it a listen, and you will be surprised).

The main problem with AI-generated music and deepfakes is the residue of artistic style that’s retained within the music generated. This opens up the world of legal actions and copyright infringement lawsuits.
Dave provides real-life scenarios of legal cases that involved legal action taken against a party as a result of similarity in the musical style amongst humans.

It is a blurred line to decide if A.I. is exempt from human laws. It’s definitely a grey area and one that doesn’t have a solid foundation of federal rules and regulation to draw from. At this moment, the case of legal action against deepfakes and A.I. is state decided.

I’m so glad I came across this article, as it’s much needed. Many readers of this article are probably developers or have a nature of work that confines them to their computer screen for a large portion of the day. Therefore, this information is invaluable to most.

There isn’t much you have to know or do when it comes to working from home, you simply sit on a desk (or lay in bed) and proceed to work as usual. The problem for me and many others is productivity and effectiveness.

Semi provides five tips that help to make the working from home life a lot easier and fruitful. She also includes tools and technologies that aid in providing the appropriate working from home environment.
After reading the tips included in the article, I realised that I might not have the best work environment setup to increase work efficiency and productivity.

But not only are there some easily immediately implementable tips, but there are also personal recollections and quirks included in this article that could make all the difference in your work output.
This article has helped me design a better work environment that is generally focused on health, communication, productivity and time management.
If you are a developer, you’ll find one or two tips that can improve your current work environment.

This next article is not so much as thought stimulating as most of the article on this list. Nonetheless, I found this article interesting as the exposure of information and knowledge should always be broadcasted, especially if the knowledge is free.
I don’t need to conduct an in-depth analysis of this article as the article itself is of a factual basis.
B. Chen brings to light a GitHub repository that contains code snippets from Jermey Howard’s yet to be released book on DeepLearning.
The value of $2000 is based on the course, and certification that is given upon the successful completion of a Deep learning course, facilitated by Jeremy Howard.
The GitHub repository contains implementations that supplement key information from the course.
The article provides more information and explanation of the nature of the repository. A lot of Deep Learning students should pay some attention to the content presented.
Understanding the difference between A.I., ML and DL!! by Rupali Roy
Springer has released 65 Machine Learning and Data books for free by Uri Eliabayev
If I had to start learning Data Science again, how would I do it? by Santiago Víquez Segura
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Machine Learning Content Creator with 1M+ views— Computer Vision Engineer. Interested in gaining and sharing knowledge on Technology and Finance
